nodes.text: Expected utility theory can be given a dynamical interpretation: agents who maximise the time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) correspond to maximising expected changes in a utility function that is the ergodicity transformation of the underlying wealth dynamics
Ergodicity economics (EE) assumes agents maximise the time-average growth rate of wealth (growth optimality) rather than expectation values over ensembles
There is a correspondence: the ergodicity transformation that extracts an ergodic growth rate from wealth dynamics can be identified with the utility function of expected utility theory (EUT)

For the equivalence between time optimisation and expected-utility optimisation to hold, the utility process u(t) must have stationary, independent additive increments and is taken here to be a Brownian motion with drift (du = a_u dt + b_u dW)

Theorem: For any invertible utility function u(x), applying Itô's lemma to u(t) following Brownian motion yields a corresponding stochastic differential equation (SDE) for wealth x(t) such that maximising expected changes in u is equivalent to maximising the time-average growth rate under that x(t)

Examples illustrate the mapping: linear utility u(x)=x corresponds to additive Brownian wealth dynamics; logarithmic utility u(x)=ln x corresponds to geometric Brownian motion (multiplicative dynamics); square-root utility produces mixed additive/multiplicative dynamics

Implication: since wealth dynamics are exogenous, the apparent utility function (and hence risk preferences) is predicted by the dynamics and will change if dynamics change, contrasting with EUT's assumption of fixed preferences

Technical derivation: starting from an arbitrary Itô process dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW, consistency with du = a_u dt + b_u dW requires relations b_u = b_x(x) u'(x) and a_u = a_x(x) u'(x) + 0.5 b_x(x)^2 u''(x), yielding conditions (and differential equations) linking drift, noise and u(x)

Wealth distributions follow from the mapping: u(t) is normal (mean a_u t, variance b_u^2 t) so the population wealth distribution P_x(x,t) = P_u(u(x),t) du/dx can be computed analytically for the corresponding dynamics
Empirical support: laboratory experiments with controllable wealth dynamics find behavior consistent with the prediction that dynamics strongly determine risk preferences

Limitation: if a wealth process does not admit an ergodicity transformation (i.e., u(t) with stationary independent increments), then EUT cannot be interpreted dynamically via this scheme and such processes may be pathological for this framework

Conclusion: the EE-EUT correspondence gives a theoretical basis for choosing utility functions (utility = ergodicity transformation) and provides a physical interpretation of utility, explaining apparent non-linear utilities as encoding non-linear wealth dynamics
